content.text:
A 61-year-old woman comes to her physician because of a change in the appearance of her right breast over the past 7 months. On physical examination the skin overlying the breast is indurated, roughened, and reddish-orange. There is nipple retraction. The gross appearance of the cut surface of her subsequent mastectomy specimen is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? <image 1> 

A. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma
B. Intraductal carcinoma
C. Phyllodes tumor
D. Lobular carcinoma in situ

The most likely diagnosis for the gross appearance of the cut surface of the mastectomy specimen shown in the image is:

A. Infiltrating ductal carcinoma

The image depicts a mass with a rough, irregular surface, which is characteristic of infiltrative ductal carcinoma. This type of cancer involves the ducts of the breast and can spread to other parts of the body. The induration, roughness, and reddish-orange appearance are also consistent with the clinical presentation of infiltrative ductal carcinoma.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
